elements.content: Three cadmium coordination polymers based on new pyridine−carboxylate and imidazole−carboxylate linkers were synthesized hydrothermally from appropriate cadmium(II) salts and the corresponding ester or benzonitrile precursor ligands. While cadmium bis[3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate] (1) adopts a three-dimensional polymeric network structure, both cadmium bis[3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate] (2) and cadmium-[4-(2-imidazolylvinyl)benzoate-acetate (3) adopt two-dimensional framework structures. In all three compounds, the carboxylate groups bridge the adjacent Cd centers to lead to centrosymmetric coordination networks. Crystal data for 1:  monoclinic space group P21/c, a = 5.054(1), b = 8.327(2), c = 30.56(1) Å, β = 92.69(1)°, and Z = 2. Crystal data for 2:  monoclinic space group P21/c, a = 5.249(3), b = 14.977(6), c = 15.755(9) Å, β = 94.57(2)°, and Z = 2. Crystal data for 3:  orthorhombic space group Pbca, a = 18.799(2), b = 7.754(1), c = 19.174(3) Å and Z = 8.

elements.content: Metal−organic coordination networks have attracted a great deal of interest in recent years owing to the aesthetically appealing nature of many network structures as well as to their potential applications in a number of areas including catalysis, magnetism, and nonlinear optics. Unlike metal oxides and other traditional inorganic materials, metal−organic coordination networks are typically synthesized by combining metal nodes of suitable geometries and desired bridging ligands under very mild conditions. The modular nature of such a synthetic approach can in principle allow precise engineering of a multitude of properties via systematic tuning of the molecular modules. A variety of interesting metal−organic hybrid materials have already emerged by judicious choice of suitable building blocks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic coordination networks have attracted a great deal of interest in recent years owing to the aesthetically appealing nature of many network structures as well as to their potential applications in a number of areas including catalysis, magnetism, and nonlinear optics. Unlike metal oxides and other traditional inorganic materials, metal-organic coordination networks are typically synthesized by combining metal nodes of suitable geometries and desired bridging ligands under very mild conditions. The modular nature of such a synthetic approach can in principle allow precise engineering of a multitude of properties via systematic tuning of the molecular modules. A variety of interesting metal-organic hybrid materials have already emerged by judicious choice of suitable building blocks.

elements.content: Over the past few years, our group has become interested in the crystal engineering of noncentrosymmetric solids based on metal−organic coordination networks for applications in second-order nonlinear optics. We rationalized that noncentrosymmetric solids could be engineered by exploiting the strong and highly directional metal−ligand coordination bonds. When metal nodes of suitable coordination geometries are combined with carefully chosen rigid bridging ligands, coordination bonds can counteract unfavorable centrosymmetric intermolecular interactions in the solid state to thus lead to noncentrosymmetric coordination networks. For example, when p-pyridinecarboxylates are used to link divalent d10 metal centers, each metal center can coordinate to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two carboxylate groups to have a maximum C 2 v symmetry and therefore will not possess a center of symmetry. Owing to the pseudo-tetrahedral connectivity of the metal centers, they can act as connecting points for a three-dimensional (3D) diamondoid network. The unsymmetrical nature of the bridging ligands ensures that each diamondoid network is acentric, and as a result the resulting solids have a very high propensity to crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups. Our work also showed that when “bent” linking groups such as m-pyridinecarboxylates were used, NLO-active polar coordination polymers with 2D grid structures could be obtained. To gain a better understanding of the factors that influence the two-dimensional (2D) and 3D network structures built from pyrdidine−carboxylate bridging ligands, we designed precursors to three new pyridine−carboxylate and imidazole−carboxylate bridging ligands and used them for the synthesis of cadmium coordination networks. Herein we report the synthesis and characterization of three cadmium coordination polymers based on pyridine−carboxylate and imidazole−carboxylate bridging ligands. Cadmium bis[3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate] (1) adopts a 3D polymeric network structure, while both cadmium bis[3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate] (2) and cadmium-[4-(2-imidazolylvinyl)benzoate-acetate (3) adopt 2D framework structures. In all three compounds, the carboxylate groups bridge the adjacent Cd centers to lead to centrosymmetric coordination networks.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. 4-Bromopyridine hydrochloride, cadmium perclorate hydrate, and cadmium acetate were purchased from TCA America, while all the other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. They were used without further purification. Caution:  Cd(ClO 4 ) 2 ·6H 2 O is potentially explosive and should be used with care! The IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets on a Perkin-Elmer Paragon 1000 FT-IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out under air on a Shimadzu TGA-50 instrument at a heating rate of 4 °C/min. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were taken on a Varian Unity-Plus 400 MHz spectrometer. Microanalyses were performed on crystalline samples by the School of Chemical Sciences Microanalytical Laboratory at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. 4-Bromopyridine hydrochloride, cadmium perclorate hydrate, and cadmium acetate were purchased from TCA America, while all the other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. They were used without further purification. Caution:  Cd(ClO  4  )  2  ⋅6H  2  O is potentially explosive and should be used with care! The IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets on a Perkin-Elmer Paragon 1000 FT-IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out under air on a Shimadzu TGA-50 instrument at a heating rate of 4 °C/min. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were taken on a Varian Unity-Plus 400 MHz spectrometer. Microanalyses were performed on crystalline samples by the School of Chemical Sciences Microanalytical Laboratory at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

elements.content: Synthesis of Methyl-3-{4-(2-pyridin-3-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate (L 1 -Me). A mixture of 3-(2-(4-bromophenylethenyl))pyridine (1.44 g, 5.0 mmol), methyl acrylate (0.7 mL, 8 mmol), palladium(II) acetate (80 mg), and tris-o-tolylphosphine (80 mg) in N,N‘-dimethylformamide (7 mL) and triethylamine (7 mL) was heated in a sealed heavy-walled tube at 110 °C for 12 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in ethyl acetate (100 mL) and washed with two portions of deionized water (50 mL). The organic layer was removed, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated dry with a rotary evaporator. Silica gel column chromatography with an eluent of ethyl acetate/hexanes (3:1 v/v) afforded 1.10 g of pure methyl-3-{4-(2-pyridin-3-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propionate (75% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 8.75 (d, 4 J H - H = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 8.51 (m, 1H), 8.45 (m, 1H), 7.84 (m, 1H), 7.70 (d, 3 J H - H = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (m, 2H), 7.31 (m, 1H), 7.13 (m, 2H), 7.10 (m, 1H), 6.47 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 15.9 Hz), 3.81 (s, 3H).

The mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in ethyl acetate (100 mL) and washed with three portions of deionized water (50 mL). The organic layer was removed, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated dry with a rotary evaporator. elements.content: Synthesis of 4-(2-Imidazolylvinyl)benzonitrile (L 3 -CN). A solution of N-vinylimidazole (0.94 g, 10 mmol) and 4-bromobenzonitrile (1.64 g, 9 mmol) in N,N‘-dimethylformamide (7 mL) and triethylamine (7 mL) was refluxed in the presence of palladium(II) acetate (120 mg) and tris-o-tolylphosphine (100 mg) for 12 h. After the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure, the residue was dissolved in ethyl acetate (150 mL) and washed with three portions of deionized water (50 mL). The organic layer was removed, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated dry with a rotary evaporator. Silica gel column chromatography with an eluent of ethyl acetate/hexanes/triethylamine (10:1:1 v/v/v) afforded 1.15 g of pure 4-(2-imidazolylvinyl)benzonitrile (60% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 7.80 (s, 1H), 7.66 (m, 2H), 7.49 (m, 2H), 7.46 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 14.7 Hz), 7.31 (m, 1H), 7.19 (m, 1H), 6.74 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 14.7 Hz).

elements.content: Synthesis of Cadmium Bis[3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate] (1). A mixture of Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O (2.1 mg, 0.005 mmol) and L 1 -Me (3.3 mg, 0.0125 mmol) was thoroughly mixed with acetonitrile (0.6 mL) and water (0.2 mL) in a heavy-walled Pyrex tube. The tube was frozen under liquid nitrogen, sealed, and placed inside an oven at 140 °C. After 18 h of heating, brown crystals of Cd(L 1 )2 were obtained. Yield:  0.0038 g (92%). Anal. Cald for C32H24N2O4Cd (%):  C, 62.7; H, 3.95; N, 4.57. Found:  C, 61.8; H, 4.12; N, 4.39. elements.content: X-ray Collections and Structure Determination. The determinations of the unit cells and data collections for all crystals of compounds 1−3 were performed on a Siemens SMART CCD. The data were collected using graphite-monochromatic Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data sets were corrected by the SADABS program. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with the SHELXTL-97 program package. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table , respectively.

1. Synthesis and Characterization. Three new ligand precursors, methyl-3-{4-(2-pyridin-3-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate (L 1 -Me), methyl-3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate (L 2 -Me), and 4-(2-imidazolylvinyl)benzonitrile (L 3 -CN) were synthesized in high yields by palladium-catalyzed Heck coupling reactions between appropriate starting materials. All of the three ligand precursors were characterized by NMR spectroscopy.

Results

 1. Synthesis and Characterization. Three new ligand precursors, methyl-3-{4-(2-pyridin-3-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate (L  1 -Me), methyl-3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate (L  2 -Me), and 4-(2-imidazolylvinyl)benzonitrile (L  3 -CN) were synthesized in high yields by palladium-catalyzed Heck coupling reactions between appropriate starting materials. All of the three ligand precursors were characterized by NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content: Brown crystals of 1 were synthesized in high yield by a hydrothermal reaction between Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O and L 1 -Me in acetonitrile and water at 140 °C (Scheme ). The methyl ester in L 1 -Me hydrolyzed to give the L 1 ligand under the hydrothermal conditions. Such an in situ hydrolysis strategy has been extensively used by our group for the synthesis of a variety of coordination polymers. The polymeric network of 1 was established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) did not show any weight loss until the decomposition of 1 at 350 °C, which is consistent with the absence of any solvent molecule in 1.

elements.content: 2. Crystal Structure of [Cd(L 1 ) 2 ]. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that 1 is of a 3D polymeric structure crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one-half cadmium atom and one L 1 ligand (Figure ). Each cadmium(II) atom is six-coordinated to four carboxylate oxygen atoms and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms that come from six different L 1 ligands. The Cd(II) center adopts a slightly distorted octahedral geometry with the Cd−O bond distances ranging from 2.294(2) to 2.301(2) Å and the Cd−N distance of 2.365(2) Å. The bond angles around the neighboring atoms range from 83.3(1) to 96.7(1)°.

elements.content: The carboxylate group bridges two metal centers so that each L 1 ligand adopts an exo-tridentate bridging fashion to link three metal centers. First, neighboring CdII centers are connected to each other by the carboxylate groups to form a one-dimensional (1D) chain that runs along the a-axis with a Cd···Cd separation of 5.054(1) Å (Figure ). These 1D chains are interconnected by the L 1 ligands via coordination with the pyridyl nitrogen atoms to form a 3D network (Figure ). Four L 1 ligands bridge four Cd atoms to form a 56-membered macrocycle ring with an opposite Cd···Cd distance of 30.56(1) Å, but the four L 1 ligands pack closely to each other and there is no room within the macrocycle to accommodate any guest molecules.

elements.content: 3. Crystal Structure of [Cd(L 2 ) 2 ]. Compound 2 also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c but adopts a 2D coordination network structure. Each Cd(II) cation adopts a slightly distorted octahedral environment by coordinating to six different L 2 ligands through two N atoms of pyridyl groups (Cd−N = 2.365(2) Å) in the axial positions and four carboxyl oxygen atoms (Cd−O = 2.299(2)−2.349(2) Å) in the equatorial positions (Figure ). The carboxylate groups of the L 2 ligands again adopt a bridging mode and link adjacent Cd centers into 1D chains that run along the b-axis with a Cd···Cd distance of 5.249(3) Å (Figure ). Unlike 1, pairs of antiparallel L 2 ligands link the same two 1D chains to result in a 2D lamellar framework lying in the ab plane.

elements.content: 4. Crystal Structure of [Cd(L 3 )(CH 3 CO 2 )]. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that compound 3 adopts a wavelike lamellar framework structure that crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbca space group. The asymmetric unit contains one Cd(II) cation, one L 3 ligand, and one acetate group. Each Cd atom is hepta-coordinated to one N atom of imidazole group (Cd−N = 2.285(4) Å), two oxygen atoms of the chelating acetate group (Cd−O = 2.338(4)−2.414(4) Å), two oxygen atoms of the chelating L 3 carboxylate group (Cd−O = 2.309(4)−2.519(5) Å), and two η2 carboxyl oxygen atoms of the acetate (Cd−O = 2.471(4) Å) and L 3 (Cd−O = 2.417(4) Å) group, respectively (Figure ).

elements.content: As shown in Figure , adjacent Cd atoms are doubly bridged by carboxyl oxygen atoms of the L 3 ligand and acetate to form linear chains along the b-axis with a neighboring Cd···Cd distance of 3.884(1) Å. These 1D chains are further propagated into an interesting wavelike 2D framework by L 3 ligands via the coordination of the imidazole nitrogen atoms. The Cd···Cd distances bridged by the L 3 ligands are 13.319(1) Å. Slightly different from 2, two L 3 ligands link two Cd atoms to form a narrow 24-membered macrocycle with the nearest Cd−Cd distance of 13.656(1) Å when viewed down the b-axis (Figure ). The neighboring layers are held together via edge···π interactions between the carboxyl O atom and vinyl group (the nearest O···C distance of 3.285 Å) and between the imidazole C atom and vinyl group (the nearest C···C distance of 3.603 Å) to lead to a supramolecular framework solid with no void space to accommodate guest molecules.

elements.content: Although our goal is to predictably synthesize noncentrosymmetric solids based on polymeric coordination networks, all the three new coordination polymers reported herein crystallize in centrosymmetric space groups. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies showed that the carboxylate groups of the new pyridine− carboxylate and imidazole−carboxylate linkers all adopt bridging coordination modes instead of chelating or monodentate coordination modes observed for rationally designed noncentrosymmetric solids we reported earlier. We previously established that when the carboxylate groups adopt either a chelating or monodentate coordination mode, the straight pyridine−carboxylate bridging ligands have a high propensity for linking the divalent metals into 3D diamondoid network structures. These diamondoid solids can be engineered to a high degree of probability and predictability to crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups. On the other hand, the bent pyridine−carboxylate bridging ligands (with either chelating or monodentate carboxylate groups) have a high tendency to link the divalent metal centers to form 2D grid structures that can also be coerced to crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups, albeit with a lower probability. The present work shows that the above design criteria fail when the carboxylate groups of the pyridine−carboxylate and imidazole−carboxylate linkers adopt bridging coordination modes. Future work is thus needed to find the metal/ligand combinations or/and synthetic conditions that would promote the adoption of chelating or monodentate coordination mode for the carboxylate groups.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Although our goal is to predictably synthesize noncentrosymmetric solids based on polymeric coordination networks, all the three new coordination polymers reported herein crystallize in centrosymmetric space groups. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies showed that the carboxylate groups of the new pyridine- carboxylate and imidazole-carboxylate linkers all adopt bridging coordination modes instead of chelating or monodentate coordination modes observed for rationally designed noncentrosymmetric solids we reported earlier. We previously established that when the carboxylate groups adopt either a chelating or monodentate coordination mode, the straight pyridine-carboxylate bridging ligands have a high propensity for linking the divalent metals into 3D diamondoid network structures. These diamondoid solids can be engineered to a high degree of probability and predictability to crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups. On the other hand, the bent pyridine-carboxylate bridging ligands (with either chelating or monodentate carboxylate groups) have a high tendency to link the divalent metal centers to form 2D grid structures that can also be coerced to crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups, albeit with a lower probability. The present work shows that the above design criteria fail when the carboxylate groups of the pyridine-carboxylate and imidazole-carboxylate linkers adopt bridging coordination modes. Future work is thus needed to find the metal/ligand combinations or/and synthetic conditions that would promote the adoption of chelating or monodentate coordination mode for the carboxylate groups.

elements.content: In this article, we have utilized three new bifunctional bridging ligands for the synthesis of three cadmium coordination networks. While 1 adopts a 3D polymeric network structure, both 2 and 3 adopt 2D framework structures. In all three compounds, the carboxylate groups bridge the adjacent Cd centers to lead to centrosymmetric coordination networks. Our current efforts are focused on finding the right metal/ligand combinations or/and synthetic conditions to promote the adoption of a chelating or monodentate coordination mode for the carboxylate groups of the pyridine−carboxylate and imidazole−carboxylate linkers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this article, we have utilized three new bifunctional bridging ligands for the synthesis of three cadmium coordination networks. While 1 adopts a 3D polymeric network structure, both 2 and 3 adopt 2D framework structures. In all three compounds, the carboxylate groups bridge the adjacent Cd centers to lead to centrosymmetric coordination networks. Our current efforts are focused on finding the right metal/ligand combinations or/and synthetic conditions to promote the adoption of a chelating or monodentate coordination mode for the carboxylate groups of the pyridine-carboxylate and imidazole-carboxylate linkers.

Synthesis of Methyl-3-{4-(2-pyridin-3-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate (L 1 -Me). A mixture of 3-(2-(4-bromophenylethenyl))pyridine (1.44 g, 5.0 mmol), methyl acrylate (0.7 mL, 8 mmol), palladium(II) acetate (80 mg), and tris-o-tolylphosphine (80 mg) in N,N‘-dimethylformamide (7 mL) and triethylamine (7 mL) was heated in a sealed heavy-walled tube at 110 °C for 12 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in ethyl acetate (100 mL) and washed with two portions of deionized water (50 mL). The organic layer was removed, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated dry with a rotary evaporator. Silica gel column chromatography with an eluent of ethyl acetate/hexanes (3:1 v/v) afforded 1.10 g of pure methyl-3-{4-(2-pyridin-3-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propionate (75% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 8.75 (d, 4 J H - H = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 8.51 (m, 1H), 8.45 (m, 1H), 7.84 (m, 1H), 7.70 (d, 3 J H - H = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (m, 2H), 7.31 (m, 1H), 7.13 (m, 2H), 7.10 (m, 1H), 6.47 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 15.9 Hz), 3.81 (s, 3H).

Synthesis of Methyl-3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate (L 2 -Me). A mixture of 4-(2-(3-bromophenylethenyl))pyridine (1.725 g, 6.01 mmol), methyl acrylate (0.7 mL, 8 mmol), palladium(II) acetate (80 mg), and tris-o-tolylphosphine (80 mg) in N,N‘-dimethylformamide (7 mL) and triethylamine (7 mL) was heated in a sealed heavy-walled tube at 110 °C for 12 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in ethyl acetate (100 mL) and washed with three portions of deionized water (50 mL). The organic layer was removed, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated dry with a rotary evaporator. Silica gel column chromatography with an eluent of ethyl acetate/hexanes (3:1 v/v) afforded 1.30 g of pure methyl-3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propionate (74% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 8.59 (m, 2H), 7.72 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 16.0 Hz), 7.67 (s, 1H), 7.56 (m, 1H), 7.48 (m, 1H), 7.43 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 7.5 Hz), 7.38 (m, 2H), 7.31 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 15 Hz), 7.10 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 15 Hz), 6.50 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 16.0 Hz), 3.80 (s, 3H).

Synthesis of 4-(2-Imidazolylvinyl)benzonitrile (L 3 -CN). A solution of N-vinylimidazole (0.94 g, 10 mmol) and 4-bromobenzonitrile (1.64 g, 9 mmol) in N,N‘-dimethylformamide (7 mL) and triethylamine (7 mL) was refluxed in the presence of palladium(II) acetate (120 mg) and tris-o-tolylphosphine (100 mg) for 12 h. After the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure, the residue was dissolved in ethyl acetate (150 mL) and washed with three portions of deionized water (50 mL). The organic layer was removed, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated dry with a rotary evaporator. Silica gel column chromatography with an eluent of ethyl acetate/hexanes/triethylamine (10:1:1 v/v/v) afforded 1.15 g of pure 4-(2-imidazolylvinyl)benzonitrile (60% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 7.80 (s, 1H), 7.66 (m, 2H), 7.49 (m, 2H), 7.46 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 14.7 Hz), 7.31 (m, 1H), 7.19 (m, 1H), 6.74 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 14.7 Hz).

Synthesis of Cadmium Bis[3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate] (1). A mixture of Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O (2.1 mg, 0.005 mmol) and L 1 -Me (3.3 mg, 0.0125 mmol) was thoroughly mixed with acetonitrile (0.6 mL) and water (0.2 mL) in a heavy-walled Pyrex tube. The tube was frozen under liquid nitrogen, sealed, and placed inside an oven at 140 °C. After 18 h of heating, brown crystals of Cd(L 1 )2 were obtained. Yield:  0.0038 g (92%). Anal. Cald for C32H24N2O4Cd (%):  C, 62.7; H, 3.95; N, 4.57. Found:  C, 61.8; H, 4.12; N, 4.39. Synthesis of Methyl-3-{4-(2-pyridin-3-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate (L  1  -Me). A mixture of 3-(2-(4-bromophenylethenyl))pyridine (1.44 g, 5.0 mmol), methyl acrylate (0.7 mL, 8 mmol), palladium(II) acetate (80 mg), and tris-o-tolylphosphine (80 mg) in N,N‘-dimethylformamide (7 mL) and triethylamine (7 mL) was heated in a sealed heavy-walled tube at 110 °C for 12 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in ethyl acetate (100 mL) and washed with  two portions of deionized water (50 mL). The organic layer was removed, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated dry with a rotary evaporator. Silica gel column chromatography with an eluent of ethyl acetate/hexanes (3:1 v/v) afforded 1.10 g of pure methyl-3-{4-(2-pyridin-3-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propionate (75% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 8.75 (d, 4 J H - H = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 8.51 (m, 1H), 8.45 (m, 1H), 7.84 (m, 1H), 7.70 (d, 3 J H - H = 15.9 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (m, 2H), 7.31 (m, 1H), 7.13 (m, 2H), 7.10 (m, 1H), 6.47 (d, 1H, 3 J H - H = 15.9 Hz), 3.81 (s, 3H).

cln_elements.content:
Three cadmium coordination polymers based on new pyridine−carboxylate and imidazole−carboxylate linkers were synthesized hydrothermally from appropriate cadmium(II) salts and the corresponding ester or benzonitrile precursor ligands. While cadmium bis[3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate] (1) adopts a three-dimensional polymeric network structure, both cadmium bis[3-{3-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl}-propenate] (2) and cadmium-[4-(2-imidazolylvinyl)benzoate-acetate (3) adopt two-dimensional framework structures. In all three compounds, the carboxylate groups bridge the adjacent Cd centers to lead to centrosymmetric coordination networks. Crystal data for 1:  monoclinic space group P21/c, a = 5.054(1), b = 8.327(2), c = 30.56(1) Å, β = 92.69(1)°, and Z = 2. Crystal data for 2:  monoclinic space group P21/c, a = 5.249(3), b = 14.977(6), c = 15.755(9) Å, β = 94.57(2)°, and Z = 2. Crystal data for 3:  orthorhombic space group Pbca, a = 18.799(2), b = 7.754(1), c = 19.174(3) Å and Z = 8.

The hydrothermal reaction of Cd(CH3CO2)2·xH2O and L 3 -CN in a mixed solvent of water and ethanol afforded colorless crystals of Cd(L3)(CH3CO2), 3 (Scheme ). The polymeric network of 3 was established by a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study. TGA result showed there was no inclusion of any solvent molecule in the framework of 3. 3 has a onset decomposition temperature of 375 °C.
